awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR: Genomic and Epigenomic Analyses of Fiber Development in Allotetraploid Cottons
awd_abstract_narration:
Cotton is the largest source of renewable textile fiber and the U.S.A. is the world's top exporter of cotton, generating ~200,000 domestic jobs. Improving cotton production will help provide U.S. jobs, sustainable agriculture, and adaptation to a changing climate. Traditional breeding efforts have given rise to several types of economically valuable cotton strains such as American and Egyptian cotton.  These two strains of cotton were independently formed by the combination of two wild species, yielding cotton strains with four sets of chromosomes (two from each parent).  This doubling of chromosomes is known as polyploidy, and this project is focused on understanding how polyploidy shapes how genes are used to generate improved strains of cotton.  This project leverages and develops cutting edge technologies in DNA sequencing to understand polyploidy.  In addition, this project produces new biological materials for cotton breeding and improvement. The research goals are augmented by promoting Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education in the Mississippi Delta through active collaborations with two Historically Black Colleges and Universities. These educational activities train college students and K-12 teachers in cutting-edge plant biotechnology techniques, knowledge, and skills to advance their careers and use in their classrooms.

Cotton is an excellent model system not only for understanding cell differentiation, elongation, and cellulose biosynthesis, but also for elucidating polyploid genome evolution and crop domestication. Upland cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.) and Pima cotton (Gossypium barbadense L.) were independently domesticated from two of five or more allotetraploid species that arose from interspecific hybridization between diploid cotton species. It is important to understand how polyploidy-induced changes in genome structure and organization, epigenetic modifications, and gene expression have enabled selection and domestication of wild allotetraploids for worldwide cotton production. The project goal is to develop high-quality genomic and epigenomic resources for cotton improvement. Comparative analyses of sequence features and gene expression diversity among domesticated and wild tetraploid and diploid relatives will reveal genomic signatures for selection and domestication of agronomic traits, including fiber yield and quality and adaptation to the environments. Laser-capture microdissection and single-cell approaches will be used to reveal genomic and epigenomic networks during the transition from protodermal to fiber cells. Functions of the selected candidate genes for fiber development and epigenetic pathways will be determined using virus-induced gene silencing and CRISPR/cas9 gene-editing tools. Genomic sequences and epigenetic resources will be released to public data depositories, including National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), Phytozome, and CottonGen. Plant materials including chromosome substitution lines and transgenic cotton will be available for the cotton breeding community. The methods, principles and resources being developed from this project will also advance the research on other polyploid crops such as wheat and canola.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background

Global institutions rely on the continued improvement of crops for food, textiles, and fuel. Cotton is the largest source of textile fiber and a major oilseed crop, with the U.S.A. being the world?s single largest cotton exporter, producing an annual crop worth ~$7B.  Increasing stresses due to climate change, pests, and diseases, require cotton producers to grow higher performing cotton. Higher performing cotton is less susceptible to diseases and pests, requires less water, and is drought resilient, all while producing high quality fiber and oilseed. Production of higher performing crops like cotton has typically been achieved through conventional breeding in which differing domesticated cotton lines with beneficial attributes are crossed to produce a superior performing cotton line. This process is repeated until a cotton line with desired characteristics is produced. Unfortunately, this process is reliant on the genetic variation currently present within the cotton population and is additionally hindered by genetic and epigenetic factors. Ultimately, the genetic composition of cotton and its interaction with the environment, present and past, dictates what beneficial attributes can be achieved and passed down to further generations. In order to circumvent these genetic and epigenetic constraints, domesticated cotton can be crossed with wild, undomesticated cotton in order to expand the genetic composition of domesticated cotton. Crossing of domesticated cotton with wild cotton results in progeny with a higher degree of genetic and epigenetic variation which can theoretically allow for the selection of higher performing cotton. Consequently, in order to productively breed domesticated cotton with wild cotton, such as those species from Central and South America, the genetic and epigenetic compositions of wild cottons must initially be determined.

Research

The goals of this project are to expand our scientific knowledge in cotton by (1) determining genomic and sequence variation of wild and domesticated species for cotton improvement, (2) testing roles for epigenomic changes in homoeologous gene expression and fiber development in domesticated tetraploid cottons and fiberless mutants, (3) determining functions of fiber-related genes and epigenetic factors using Virus Induced Gene Silencing (VIGS) and CRISPR/cas9 gene-editing technology, and (4) managing and disseminating cotton genome sequence and epigenome information for the cotton and plant research communities.

 

Over three-hundred wild cotton accessions from Central and South America were assessed for genomic and genetic characterization (sequencing) of which sixty were ultimately chosen. These sixty cotton accessions were sequenced and their relationships to one another were determined, and ten representative wild cotton accessions were selected for high quality sequencing using some of the most advanced sequencing techniques available. Additionally, RNA for these accessions was isolated, allowing for RNA-sequencing validation and accurate annotation of genes within these genomes. These ten cotton genomes coupled with precision gene annotation will provide the scientific community with genomic tools to better understand both cotton and plant genetics and genomics which is vital for cotton and crop improvement.

The methylation context of the selected ten wild cotton accessions has been determined through bisulfite-sequencing which allows for the characterization of epigenetic modification on various traits such as gene expression and fiber development. This allows us to understand how environmental modification of the genome, in this case through methylation, can affect the expression of traits in future generations. 

Additionally, transgenic cotton has been generated that allows for the study of fiber related gene expression over time and a stable genetic transformation system has also been developed that takes only half as long as standard transformation methods. The latter is of particular importance as cotton is notorious in its recalcitrance of genetic transformation ? it is difficult to artificially introduce external genes into cotton which is why the classical method of breeding different cotton lines for improvement is primarily used. This new transformation system will expedite our understanding of gene expression related to traits of interest for the purposes of cotton improvement. 

Education and Outreach

These research objectives were augmented by promoting Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education in the Mississippi Delta through active collaborations with two Historically Black Colleges and Universities: Alcorn State University (ASU) and Mississippi Valley State University (MSVU). Through the Science Teacher Enhancement Program (STEP), high school teachers from surrounding counties attended multi-day workshops at ASU, with hands-on modules to improve science pedagogy in biology, math and chemistry at the high school level. A total of 32 high school teachers participated in the STEP program, going on to improve the college readiness of students at participating high schools. At the collegiate level, students from both MSVU and ASU participated in intensive internships through HudsonAlpha?s BioTrain program. This 9-week course connected the students? classwork with real-world experience and training in bioinformatics and biotechnology, preparing them for careers in those fields, and provided opportunities to present their research at scientific meetings.
